entry.title: How Do We Create Meaningful Many Dimensional Space?
entry.content:
This post should be the third notes on understanding fundamentals of Analysis, or in a more broad sense, understanding fundamental of Mathematics, though some other randoms post are written previously. The first is about the axiomization of Natural Number. It gives the exact definition of natural number, whose concept is taken for granted for most people. The second is about the construction of Real Number System. It offers a complete field which all the remaining Mathematics is built on.

The above two posts are both in essential, one dimensional. They are the infrastructure of univariate function, univariate calculus and other univariate Math subjects. After building the one dimensional infrastructure, the next step is to step in the world of more than one – two dimensional, three dimensional, finite dimensional, and the infinite dimensional, which all will be called many dimensional space in this post.

So this is about how do we create meaningful many dimensional space that suitable for the real world problem. In such space, we could deal with, two dimensional plane, three dimensional space, ultimately countably infinite dimensional space and uncountably infinite dimensional space, furthermore, the one of the most important subjects in modern analysis – function space.

The Leap to Abstract Mathematics

Such transition is a great leap in the development of Mathematics. It makes Mathematics become more and more abstract. The inevitability is showed in the following. As having been numbered before, there are at least four extremely common many dimensional space we must deal with: two dimensional, three dimensional, which we are familiar with; countably infinite dimensional space, for instance, countable sequences, which is quite common; uncountably infinite dimensional space, for instance the space of all continuous function defined on $R$, which some may not be very familiar. Actually, there is a lot more than that since at least we would have a number of spaces such as 7D and 8D etc.. So mathematicians cannot deal with those spaces be copying the way they deal with $R$. They have to find a way to see those thing in common. In the popular word of programmers, they need to abstract them. Ha ha, programming is great, right?

Consequently, here comes Abstract Algebra, General Topology and ultimately, Functional Analysis. Let get to know what these three terms are about(but it is highly probable that you have no idea what I am talking about given learning Math is far from learning concepts): Abstract Algebra is about abstracting common operations that is used in $R$, which is called using the terminology algebraic structure. For instance, a ring is an algebraic structure with operations generalizing the arithmetic operations of addition and multiplication. So such operation will not only be able to be applied to number, but to polynomials, matrices and etc..[1] More word may be find in this rather old post on Basic of Algebra Structure; General Topology is about the mathematical study of shapes and topological spaces. It is an area of mathematics concerned with the properties of space that are preserved under continuous deformations including stretching and bending, but not tearing or gluing[2]. The sets with the same properties are called open set. Abstract Algebra abstracts operations of $R$. General Topology abstracts objects or points of $R$. With objects and operations on those objects, we could analyze them, where comes Functional Analysis(Though Functional Analysis is just about analyze functions, all machinery developed above is to try to deal with function space. So the problem and technique in Functional Analysis could all be applied to other many dimensional space).

Hilbert Space

Once we have abstract stuff, things could become very weird given that we could tweak the stuff anyway we want. But the key is to remember why we initiate the search for an abstract solution for solving real world problem. So the light to guide the abstract construction is to let things meet natural intuitions. This is the point I learned hardest while teaching myself functional analysis, which is the thread that guides me to bridge the gap between those highly abstract concepts to the details in the real world problems I aim to solve.

Hilbert Space is the solution to the question posed at the beginning – finding a meaningful many dimensional space. From now on, why Hilbert Space fits with natural intuition will be elaborated. But keep in mind that though understanding intuition playing a very important role in learning Mathematics, it is never sufficient, a large amount of information is skipped at the time Abstract Algebra and General Topology is introduced above. It is the process to learning them, to do exercise that gives me such intuition.

A natural step following one number, denoted $\xi$, is to list a tuple $(\xi_{1}, \xi_{2})$. $\xi_{1}$ could be the size of one department and $\xi_{2}$ could be the price of the department. We take it in tuple maybe because to want to investigate something that is related to those two both. Then naturally, we would like to extend it to $(\xi_{1} \ldots \xi_{n})$, then $(\xi_{1} \ldots \xi_{n}), n = 1 \ldots \infty$, which is called countably infinite, then $(\xi_{1} \ldots \xi_{n})$, where we regard $\xi_{i}$ is as dense(note the dense does not mean its usual meaning in topology) as point in $R$(this sentence is actually mathematically wrong given the incountablity of the set, but it makes the point through more easily), which is called uncountably finite. Each instance of previous examples is a point in its space. For instance, $(\xi_{1} \ldots \xi_{n}), n = 1 \ldots \infty$ is a point in the space of all possible value of $\xi_{i}$. The point is actually called vector and the space is noted as Vector Space defined on Field $R$ or $C$ if it is complex.

Again, the natural question to ask is how much similarity with $R$ we could keep while generalizing? This is the process we construct the meaningful many dimensional space. The answer is that we want to get completeness, compactness, connectivity, which are contents of topology and metric space, “absolute value” of point, which is the content of Normed Vector Space, “length” of “lines” which is the content of Real Analysis and others. Given the limitation of time, none of them will be covered here. The point of this post is to try to note down the hardest to understood properties kept after generalization – geometric intuition on 2D or 3D space.

What is the geometric intuition I am talking about?

In Normed Vector Space, we could assign any norm we want, for instance, $L^{p}$ norm. But it seems 2-norm, also Euclidean norm that is the most natural norm for we human. But why it is the most natural one? How do we define natural?

The following are some direct answer:

Geometric Proof of Pythagoras Theorem

  1. As we rotate one vector, its length will not change in 2-norm, but not other norms.
  2. It makes Pythagoras Theorem held. So when we drop the coordinate system, and see vectors in pure geometric way, its length will still be the same.

But those all special phenomenon of one underlying truth – 2-norm could be derived from inner product(Besides completeness, it is inner product that plays the most important role in the definition of Hilbert Space), and inner product gives angle a sensible definition.

Before we elaborate the point, let us think a minute about what exactly angle is? This is again one blind spot that we take for granted, at least me.

Try searching on its wikipedia page. Actually we cannot define angle like we define natural number using Peano Axiom. We are told it is some thing that is between two straight line or defined it through trigonometric function, which is essentially ratio, in high school. Underlying those definition, we are actually define it through its behavior. This makes sense, since ultimately, angles do not exist on their own and are the relation between lines.

But we could model such relationship using one entity – inner product. Angle could be defined as:

Through this way, angle is connected with value(coordinates) of lines(vectors) naturally. As angle is kept, our intuition is actually kept. More specifically the intuition of rotation, orthogonality and projection are all kept. Those are what we call natural.

To make sense of it, it is recommended to prove polarization identity using property of inner product and law of cosine using elementary geometry method(polarization identity and law of cosine are the same theorem in different names in different contexts).

Reference

  2. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topology

entry.title: How to Understand Compact in Mathematical Analysis
entry.content:
Preface

My journey of teaching myself mathematics begins with learning the number theory, understanding why matrix is invented. Thus up to now, most of the effort was spent on matrix algebra and matrix calculus.

Recently, I am trying to understand wavelet theory. The main motivation behind it is to find a set of basis to approximate functions, which seems to involve a lot of analysis. Therefore, I beginning to teach myself analysis like a math major student from scratch.

This post is about another concept called compact. You can find previous post about real number system here.

Definitions

Definition A subset $K$ of metric space $X$ is said to be compact if every open cover of $K$ contains a finite subcover.

As a number of other mathematical definition, they have reused the structure built before, which means they have a lot of information beneath the surface. So let’s define what is

  1. metric space, this one is assumed to be known.
  2. open cover
  3. finite
  4. subcover

open cover

Definition By an open cover of a set $E$ in a metric space $X$ we mean a collection of open subsets of $X$ such that .

The concept of open is assumed to be known.

It is a rather mathematical definition, however, as having been emphasized over and over, there is always a simple intuition behind one abstract idea. The intuition of open cover is to use open, which means we do not make arbitrary judgement about the boundary of the ball ball to cover the area that is taken up by the $E$. The idea of compact is to accumulate those no judgemental balls to acquire some global properties about the set. As we will see later.

subcover

A subcover is one element of . The intuition is that one subcover is just one open ball.

finite

Though the concept of finite and infinite predates college, it seems that I do not pay enough attention to them till now. But note that even without mentioning this concept, the meaning of finite in the definition of compact is still straightforward.

Definition For any positive integer n, let $J_{n}$ be the set whose elements are the integers $1, 2, \ldots, n$; let $J$ be the set consisting of all positive integers. For any set $A$, we say:

  1. $A$ is finite if $A ~ J_{n}$ for some $n$ (the empty set is also considered to be finite).
  2. $A$ is infinite if $A$ is not finite.
  3. $A$ is countable if $A ~ J$.
  4. $A$ is uncountable if $A$ is neither finite nor countable.
  5. $A$ is at most countable if $A$ is finite or countable.

The above definition uses the notion of equivalence.

Equivalence

Definition If there exists a $1-1$ mapping of $A$ onto $B$, we say that $A$ and $B$ can be put in $1-1$ correspondence, or that $A$ and $B$ have the same cardinal number, or briefly, that $A$ and $B$ are equivalent, and we write $A \sim B$.

compact explained

Now, let’s try to understand the idea of compact. First we see one set that is not compact. Then we try to see the reason why compact is put forward. The main intuition is, I think, which is not cited from anywhere else, so it may be wrong, that the introduce of compact bridges the gap between the set’s global properties and local properties, infinite properties and finite properties.

Example

The open interval $I = (0, 1)$ is not compact.

To see why, let . Each is an open cover of $I$ and as $n \rightarrow \infty$, could cover $I$. However, if we only take finite number of subcover of , we cannot cover $I$.

However, if we let $I$ to be a closed interval, say $I = [0, 1]$, it is compact. A general theorem about this is described as every k-cell(try Google what k-cell is if you have no idea what it is) is compact. Proof here will be omitted(Proof can be found on Theorem 2.40 of Ref 1). The intuition behind the proof is that if an open cover $G$ could be found, then if any finite subcovers of $G$ cannot cover the k-cell, you can always add more but finite number of subcovers to cover all of $G$.

So why only a difference of open and closed makes such a difference?

In my view, the key difference is the limit point. If we do not makes arbitrary statement about the limit point, which is the boundary in this case, abnormal phenomenon could happen when approaching the limit point. As in this case, when point, denoted $x$, is approaching zero, if some function $f$ defined on the interval and $f$ has $x$ in the denominator, $f$ may be boundless.

Thus, compact models the process that a point is approaching its limit step by step(open ball by open ball) without making arbitrary statement about the boundary. Consequently, compact has a number of connection with continuity and convergence.

In the following, we would see more examples that compact is in action to have a feeling about its effect.

Before that, let us introduce an important theorem that connect finite with infinite.

Theorem If is a collection of compact subsets of a metric space $X$ such that intersection of every finite subcollection of is nonempty, then $$\cap K_{\alpha}$$ is nonempty.

Proof Fix a member of and put . Assume that no point of belongs to every . Then the sets form an open cover of ; and since is compact, there are finitely many indices such that . But this means that is empty, in contradiction to our hypothesis.

Corollary If is a sequence of nonempty compact sets such that , then is not empty.

This corollary actually bridges finite and infinite together.

Now, let’s see the theorem in action.

Theorem Let $P$ be a nonempty perfect set in $R^{k}$. Then $P$ is uncountable.

Proof Since $P$ has limits points, $P$ must be infinite. Suppose $P$ is countable, we denote the points of $P$ by By analysis the interval between those points, we could find the contradiction we want.

Let be the neighborhood of . If consists of all $y \in R^{k}$ such that , then the closure of is the set of all $y \in R^{k}$ such that .

Suppose has been constructed, so that is not empty. Since every point of $P$ is a limit point of $P$, there is a neighborhood such that 1. , 2. , 3. is not empty. The induction goes on.

Put . Since is closed and bounded, is compact(Theorem 2.41 Ref 1). Since , not point of $P$ is in . Since , this implies that is empty. But each is nonempty, by 3, and by 1, this contradicts the corollary above.

Proof is complete.

In this proof, the global property of the $P$ is proved by reducing the contradiction into infinite intersection of small sets of $P$. This shows some feelings about the bridge mentioned above.

One More Example

Theorem Compact subsets of metric spaces are closed.

Proof The proof also starts from the intuition that if the subset is open, we cannot approach the boundary of the subset, since they are not part of the set, in a finite step.

Before we prove the theorem, a common misunderstanding of the compact should be pointed out. It is also straightforward to think that if one set $G$ is compact, it could be covered by a finite subcover, therefore, any subsets of $G$ could also be covered by such subcover. Consequently, any subsets of $G$ is also compact.

The misunderstanding under this reasoning is that compact is defined by all open covers, which means it has to rule out all possible open covers. Note that the open covers of $G$ cannot cover all open covers of its subsets. For example, a open cover could cover one subset $G_i$ of $G$, which indeed is an open cover of $G_i$, but this open cover is not one of $G$.

Now, the proof is begun(Ref 2).

We want to prove if $A \subseteq X$ is not closed, then $A$ is not compact. We tackle the problem from the boundary. Since $A$ is not closed, there is one point $p \in (cl, A) but \notin A$. For $n \in N^{+}$, let

$U_n$ is a open cover of $A$, however, no finite subsets of $U_n$ would cover $A$.

One More Example…

Theorem Closed subsets of compact sets are compact.

Proof Ref 1. The intuition behind this proof is that for each finite open cover of $K$, there exists a finite subcover that could cover $F$, which means $F$ is compact.

Suppose $F \subset K \subset X$, $F$ is closed (relative to $X$), and $K$ is compact. Let ${V_{\alpha}}$ be an open cover of $F$. If we add one more open set $F^{c}$, then ${V_{\alpha}} \cup F^{c}$ becomes the open cover of $K$. Since $K$ is compact, there exists finite subcovers that would cover $K$. By excluding $F^{c}$, those subcovers are also a finite cover of $F$, which means $F$ is compact.

One More Examples

Proof is finished. Ref 3

To see why compact is necessary, see this example below.

Let , each intersection between $I_m$ and $I_n$ is not empty, however, as $n \rightarrow \infty$, the intersection is empty.

This example shows that compact is mainly aims at the limit property of set.

The intuition underlies this also related to the intuition put forward at the first place. If we can guarantee one point in the set in the finite case, we could also guarantee it in the infinite case. It bridges the gap between finite and infinite.

entry.title: Why and How We Construct Real Number System
entry.content:
Preface

My journey of teaching myself mathematics begins with learning the number theory, understanding why matrix is invented. Thus up to now, most of the effort was spent on matrix algebra and matrix calculus.

Recently, I am trying to understand wavelet theory. The main motivation behind it is to find a set of basis to approximate functions, which seems to involve a lot of analysis. Therefore, I beginning to teach myself analysis like a math major student from scratch.

The first hard concept I met is the construction of real number system. I skipped this concept the first time I am learning analysis. In retrospect, I mainly focused on the concept of peano axiom to construct natural number system then because matrix algebra mainly deals with integer. However, the main objective of wavelet theory is to find a set of basis that can approximate functions, regardless of continuous and discrete. There is no escape this time.

The articles about peano axiom is on another PDF file, which I haven’t sorted it out on the blog. Some time in the future.

I guess this will be the beginning of a series of post about analysis. The first one here is about construction of real number system. Let us begin.

Some Words

The purpose of this post is to explain the intuition behind to construct the real number system, so it will not be mathematically sound and incremental. You should be familiar with the following concept:

  1. (ordered)field
  2. ordered set
  3. some knowledge about set and set operation
  4. Cauchy sequence
  5. Archimedean property

Motivation Sketch

The following are key points that motivate mathematicians to construct a new number theory that is called real number system.

  1. There are numbers that rational number cannot incorporate. In other word, there is gaps in rational number line.
  2. It may be surprising that for some $E \subset Q$, you cannot find the extreme point of $E$ in $Q$. This point is somehow a rephrase of the previous point – there are gaps and least upper bound may residue in the gap.

Therefore, to make the number line to be without gaps, in our daily word, continuous, the real number system is constructed.

Folk Story

For most practical purposes in our daily life, the Field of Rational can be said to be more than adequate as a number system. After all, when we take a measurement with our ruler, we can read at best to the markings on the ruler and those markings are simply fractions of the length of the ruler. Even when we use an electronic calculator and obtained a result whose figures covered the whole screen, we simply round off to our desired accuracy with not much complaint. Now, when we round off something, we are simply getting a result that can be expressed as a fraction. So what exactly is wrong with the Field of Rational?

Most people’s idealization of the real numbers is that they are markings on an imaginary number line. This number line is a sort of conceptual ruler that mathematicians can use to measure their abstract objects exactly. This means that the number line will always give us the exact value, and not just any approximated value, of any quantity we are measuring. Of course, some sort of standardization of the division mark should be used so that everybody’s absolute value agree but that is beside the point. Now, if the Field of Rational gives us such an ideal number system, then we should be able to cover the whole of the number line with rational numbers. If this cannot be achieved, then there will be at least one point on the number line that have no markings, and what value are we going to assign an object whose length happen to hit that mark?

Inadequacy of $Q$

Gap in $Q$

Theorem: There exists no rational $r$ such that $r^{2} = 2$.

Suppose that such $r$ does exist. We may assume that $r > 0$, otherwise we take $-r$.

Any rational number could be expressed in the form of $\frac{n}{m}$, great command divisor of $m, n$ will be one, thus $n$ and $m$ will not be both even.

In the equation above, $n^{2}$ will be even, thus $n$ will be even. Consequently, $m$ will be even, which contradict with the prerequisite that $n, m$ will not be both even.

Therefore, $r$ will not belong to $Q$.

No extremum point in some set in $Q$

To see this, we also consider the example of square root of 2.

For every $p$ in $A$ we can find a rational $q$ in $A$ such that $p < q$ and for every $p$ in $B$ we can find a rational $q$ in $B$ such that $q < p$.

To do this, we associate with each rational $p > 0$ the number

If $p$ is in $A$ then $p^{2} - 2 < 0$, we have $q > p$ and $q \in A$. The case when $p$ is in $B$ is visa vice.

From this example, we find that we cannot find the maximum of one set in $Q$, which contradict with our intuition that the number line is continuous. To make the number line continuous, the real number system is constructed.

least-upper-bound property

Before we construct the real number system, we first define some relevant definition.

Definition Suppose $S$ is an ordered set, and $E \subset S$. If there exists a $\beta \in S$ such that $x \leq \beta$ for every $x \in E$, we say that $E$ is bounded above, and call $\beta$ an upper bound of $E$.

Lower bound is defined in the same way.

Definition Suppose $S$ is an ordered set, $E \subset S$, and $E$ is bounded above. Suppose there exists an $\alpha \in S$ with the following properties:

  1. $\alpha$ is an upper bound of $E$.
  2. If $\gamma < \alpha$ then $\gamma$ is not an upper bound of $E$.

Then $\alpha$ is called the least upper bound of $E$ or supremum of $E$, and we write

The greatest lower bound or infimum, of a set $E$ which is bounded below is defined in the same manner, denoted as $\alpha = inf E$.

Definition An ordered set $S$ is said to have the least-upper-bound property if the following is true:

If $E \subset S$, $E$ is not empty, and $E$ is bounded above, then $sup E$ exists in $S$.

Real Number System

Theorem There exists an ordered field $R$ which has the least-upper-bound property.

The members of $R$ is are called real numbers.

Now we stop for a moment and to reiterate the understanding one should possess when reaching this point. The gaps in rational number line motivate mathematicians to construct real number system $R$, and the most essential traits which makes $R$ different from $Q$ is that $R$ has least-upper-bound property, which means it has its extreme in its own.

So, how could we construct such a system, called real number system by us, that fulfills least-upper-bound property?

The intuition of two approaches will sketched. The first one is Cantor’s approach and the second one is Dedekind’s approach. Cantor’s approach is described first since it is easier for me to understanding when learning.
